A crucial role in mitigating climate change is played by electric grids. To successfully address this challenge in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), increasing operational efficiency is key. This demands evolving knowledge of the grid's state, with topology being a fundamental aspect. Topology refers to how points on the network are physically connected. In LMICs, knowledge of distribution topology is limited, and existing methods for topology estimation rely on expensive sensing infrastructure, such as smart meters or PMUs, which are inaccessible at scale. This paper lays the foundation for topology estimation from more accessible data: outlet-level voltage magnitude measurements. It presents a graph-based algorithm and visualization using the Fiedler vector for estimating and communicating topological proximity from this data. The method is demonstrated on a real dataset collected in Accra, Ghana, opening the possibility of globally accessible, cutting-edge grid monitoring through non-traditional sensing strategies coupled with machine learning.

Climate change mitigation is a twin challenge: decarbonizing energy production and meeting global energy needs. Electric grids play a central role in addressing this challenge and must adapt to deliver electricity between new generation technologies and increasing consumer demand. In LMICs, where per capita energy consumption is expected to grow dramatically despite limited investment in grid infrastructure, this growth will require new levels of efficiency and responsiveness in grid operations. This new operating approach should maximize the longevity of existing infrastructure and precisely target costly upgrades.

Efficient operation of an electrical grid requires evolving knowledge of the grid's state, including its topology. Topology is a key piece of information that can enable loss reduction by identifying connections for phase re-balancing, locating lossy equipment, and targeting load re-distribution to prolong equipment life. Topological awareness can also help localize the root causes of outages for quicker restoration and reduced use of polluting backup generation. Unfortunately, knowledge of distribution grid topology is often poor or erroneous, especially in urban areas of LMICs.

Existing solutions for topology estimation demand advanced sensing, such as smart meters or PMUs. However, these devices are expensive to purchase, install, and operate, and therefore largely absent from LMIC distribution networks. This work demonstrates topology estimation in LMICs by lowering the necessary sensing requirements. By proposing a modification of the transformation and a new visualization, we uncover rich topological information about the proximity of grid nodes from lower-cost, less-precise voltage magnitude sensors at the network edge.

We present an initial evaluation of the proposed method in three selected case studies. The case studies expand upon our base method by adding creative sensor deployment strategies and fusing auxiliary data types from the same sensor, including event-triggered point-on-wave snapshots. These case studies lay a promising foundation for topology estimation from low-cost sensor deployments that are designed for the constraints of LMIC grids.

Our topology estimation method is validated on a dataset from 1,276 PowerWatch sensors deployed in Accra, Ghana. The PowerWatch sensors cost less than 1% of commercially available PMU sensors and have been deployed at scale to monitor grid reliability in LMIC contexts. The sensors plug into customer wall outlets and report voltage magnitude, frequency, and power state every two minutes. Due to limited GPS availability indoors, data is only provided with second-level timestamps, which precludes the use of topology algorithms that require precise time-synchronization across sensors.

The sensors are deployed in groups of generally 3 but up to 20 sensors called "sites" to monitor a single transformer. As several hundred customers can be served by a transformer, this is an enormous but necessary undersampling, reflecting a reality for topology estimation in LMICs: comprehensive sensing of the distribution network is essentially impossible. We present four case studies in Accra: two at densely deployed sites, a third at many sites spread along Aburi Road, and a fourth at two sites around Darkuman Road. In the latter case studies, voltage magnitude data is compared with two other data types—outage data and point-on-wave (POW)—to demonstrate the value of data fusion for topology recovery.
